poem:
### Small Acts

Deliver milk in glass, clink 
the bottle's song against the doorstep.  
Sparkling water births  
from humble kitchens, dreams 
bubbling to fizz. Ditch the teabag, 
a paper prayer in the morning cup.  
Plastic shrinks, an invisible tide  
receding with each choice— 
tin soldier warriors in gardens  
fighting for a quieter, cleaner world.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Get milk delivered and always buy refills: 20 simple ways to cut down on plastic (and save money) We all want to use less plastic, but it’s not always easy. So we asked you – readers of the Filter, along with friends, family and colleagues – how you cut down on plastic in your lives. From making your own sparkling water to ditching teabags, here are all the ways you’re helping save the planet, one". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
